description:
Eptesicus fuscus, commonly known as the big brown bat, is a species of bat belonging to the family Vespertilionidae. It is a medium-sized bat, typically weighing between 12-25 grams and having a wingspan of 32-40 cm.

The big brown bat has a distinctive brown or reddish-brown fur, with a slightly darker face and ears. Its ears are short and rounded, and its wings are broad and leathery. The species is widely distributed across North America, ranging from southern Canada to central Mexico.

Eptesicus fuscus is an insectivorous bat, feeding primarily on a variety of insects, such as beetles, moths, and flies. It is a nocturnal species, emerging at dusk to forage for its prey. The big brown bat is known for its ability to navigate and locate its prey using echolocation, emitting high-frequency calls and listening for the returning echoes.

This species is often found roosting in buildings, caves, and tree cavities, and can form large colonies during the summer months. Eptesicus fuscus is an important part of the ecosystem, as it helps to control insect populations and plays a role in the dispersal of seeds and pollination of plants.
